trans-unit.source: Getting started with elastic database jobs
trans-unit.target: Getting started with elastic database jobs

trans-unit.source: how to use elastic database jobs
trans-unit.target: how to use elastic database jobs

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database jobs (preview) for Azure SQL Database allows you to reliability execute T-SQL scripts that span multiple databases while automatically retrying and providing eventual completion guarantees.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database jobs (preview) for Azure SQL Database allows you to reliability execute T-SQL scripts that span multiple databases while automatically retrying and providing eventual completion guarantees.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Elastic Database job feature, please see the <linkText>feature overview page</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Elastic Database job feature, please see the <linkText>feature overview page</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This topic extends the sample found in <linkText>Getting started with Elastic Database tools</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This topic extends the sample found in <linkText>Getting started with Elastic Database tools</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When completed, you will: learn how to create and manage jobs that manage a group of related databases.
trans-unit.target: When completed, you will: learn how to create and manage jobs that manage a group of related databases.

trans-unit.source: Download and run the <linkText>Getting started with Elastic Database tools sample</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Download and run the <linkText>Getting started with Elastic Database tools sample</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Here you will create a shard map manager along with several shards, followed by insertion of data into the shards.
trans-unit.target: Here you will create a shard map manager along with several shards, followed by insertion of data into the shards.

trans-unit.source: If you happen to already have shards setup with sharded data in them, you can skip the following steps and move to the next section.
trans-unit.target: If you happen to already have shards setup with sharded data in them, you can skip the following steps and move to the next section.

trans-unit.source: Build and run the Getting started with Elastic Database tools sample application.
trans-unit.target: Build and run the Getting started with Elastic Database tools sample application.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps until step 7 in the section <linkText>Download and run the sample app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps until step 7 in the section <linkText>Download and run the sample app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: At the end of Step 7, you will see the following command prompt:
trans-unit.target: At the end of Step 7, you will see the following command prompt:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>command prompt</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>command prompt</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the command window, type "1" and press Enter.
trans-unit.target: In the command window, type "1" and press Enter.

trans-unit.source: This creates the shard map manager, and adds two shards to the server.
trans-unit.target: This creates the shard map manager, and adds two shards to the server.

trans-unit.source: Then type "3" and press Enter; repeat the action four times.
trans-unit.target: Then type "3" and press Enter; repeat the action four times.

trans-unit.source: This inserts sample data rows in your shards.
trans-unit.target: This inserts sample data rows in your shards.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title> should show three new databases in your v12 server:
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title> should show three new databases in your v12 server:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Visual Studio confirmation</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Visual Studio confirmation</linkText>

trans-unit.source: At this point, we will create a custom database collection that reflects all the databases in the shard map.
trans-unit.target: At this point, we will create a custom database collection that reflects all the databases in the shard map.

trans-unit.source: This will allow us to create and execute a job that add a new table across shards.
trans-unit.target: This will allow us to create and execute a job that add a new table across shards.

trans-unit.source: Now here we would usually create a shard map target, using the New-AzureSqlJobTarget cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Now here we would usually create a shard map target, using the New-AzureSqlJobTarget cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The shard map manager database must be set as a database target and then the specific shard map is specified as a target.
trans-unit.target: The shard map manager database must be set as a database target and then the specific shard map is specified as a target.

trans-unit.source: Instead, we are going to enumerate all the databases in the server and add the databases to the new custom collection with the exception of master database.
trans-unit.target: Instead, we are going to enumerate all the databases in the server and add the databases to the new custom collection with the exception of master database.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell script can be used to execute an existing job:
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell script can be used to execute an existing job:

trans-unit.source: Update the following variable to reflect the desired job name to have executed:
trans-unit.target: Update the following variable to reflect the desired job name to have executed:

trans-unit.source: Use the same Get-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet with the IncludeChildren parameter to view the state of child job executions, namely the specific state for each job execution against each database targeted by the job.
trans-unit.target: Use the same Get-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet with the IncludeChildren parameter to view the state of child job executions, namely the specific state for each job execution against each database targeted by the job.

trans-unit.source: The Get-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet has multiple optional parameters that can be used to display multiple job executions, filtered through the provided parameters.
trans-unit.target: The Get-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet has multiple optional parameters that can be used to display multiple job executions, filtered through the provided parameters.

trans-unit.source: The following demonstrates some of the possible ways to use Get-AzureSqlJobExecution:
trans-unit.target: The following demonstrates some of the possible ways to use Get-AzureSqlJobExecution:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all active top level job executions:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all active top level job executions:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all top level job executions, including inactive job executions:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all top level job executions, including inactive job executions:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all child job executions of a provided job execution ID, including inactive job executions:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all child job executions of a provided job execution ID, including inactive job executions:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all job executions created using a schedule / job combination, including inactive jobs:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all job executions created using a schedule / job combination, including inactive jobs:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all jobs targeting a specified shard map, including inactive jobs:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all jobs targeting a specified shard map, including inactive jobs:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve all jobs targeting a specified custom collection, including inactive jobs:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve all jobs targeting a specified custom collection, including inactive jobs:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve the list of job task executions within a specific job execution:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve the list of job task executions within a specific job execution:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve job task execution details:
trans-unit.target: Retrieve job task execution details:

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell script can be used to view the details of a job task execution, which is particularly useful when debugging execution failures.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell script can be used to view the details of a job task execution, which is particularly useful when debugging execution failures.

trans-unit.source: The JobTaskExecution object includes a property for the Lifecycle of the task along with a Message property.
trans-unit.target: The JobTaskExecution object includes a property for the Lifecycle of the task along with a Message property.

trans-unit.source: If a job task execution failed, the Lifecycle property will be set to Failed and the Message property will be set to the resulting exception message and its stack.
trans-unit.target: If a job task execution failed, the Lifecycle property will be set to Failed and the Message property will be set to the resulting exception message and its stack.

trans-unit.source: If a job did not succeed, it is important to view the details of job tasks that did not succeed for a given job.
trans-unit.target: If a job did not succeed, it is important to view the details of job tasks that did not succeed for a given job.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell script can be used to wait for a job task to complete:
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell script can be used to wait for a job task to complete:

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database jobs supports creating custom execution policies that can be applied when starting jobs.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database jobs supports creating custom execution policies that can be applied when starting jobs.

trans-unit.source: Execution policies currently allow for defining:
trans-unit.target: Execution policies currently allow for defining:

trans-unit.source: Name: Identifier for the execution policy.
trans-unit.target: Name: Identifier for the execution policy.

trans-unit.source: Job Timeout: Total time before a job will be canceled by Elastic Database Jobs.
trans-unit.target: Job Timeout: Total time before a job will be canceled by Elastic Database Jobs.

trans-unit.source: Initial Retry Interval: Interval to wait before first retry.
trans-unit.target: Initial Retry Interval: Interval to wait before first retry.

trans-unit.source: Maximum Retry Interval: Cap of retry intervals to use.
trans-unit.target: Maximum Retry Interval: Cap of retry intervals to use.

trans-unit.source: Retry Interval Backoff Coefficient: Coefficient used to calculate the next interval between retries.
trans-unit.target: Retry Interval Backoff Coefficient: Coefficient used to calculate the next interval between retries.

trans-unit.source: The following formula is used: (Initial Retry Interval) * Math.pow((Interval Backoff Coefficient), (Number of Retries) - 2).
trans-unit.target: The following formula is used: (Initial Retry Interval) * Math.pow((Interval Backoff Coefficient), (Number of Retries) - 2).

trans-unit.source: Maximum Attempts: The maximum number of retry attempts to perform within a job.
trans-unit.target: Maximum Attempts: The maximum number of retry attempts to perform within a job.

trans-unit.source: The default execution policy uses the following values:
trans-unit.target: The default execution policy uses the following values:

trans-unit.source: Name: Default execution policy
trans-unit.target: Name: Default execution policy

trans-unit.source: Job Timeout: 1 week
trans-unit.target: Job Timeout: 1 week

trans-unit.source: Initial Retry Interval: 100 milliseconds
trans-unit.target: Initial Retry Interval: 100 milliseconds

trans-unit.source: Maximum Retry Interval: 30 minutes
trans-unit.target: Maximum Retry Interval: 30 minutes

trans-unit.source: Retry Interval Coefficient: 2
trans-unit.target: Retry Interval Coefficient: 2

trans-unit.source: Maximum Attempts: 2,147,483,647
trans-unit.target: Maximum Attempts: 2,147,483,647

trans-unit.source: Create the desired execution policy:
trans-unit.target: Create the desired execution policy:

trans-unit.source: Update the desired execution policy to update:
trans-unit.target: Update the desired execution policy to update:

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database Jobs supports cancellation requests of jobs.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database Jobs supports cancellation requests of jobs.

trans-unit.source: If Elastic Database Jobs detects a cancellation request for a job currently being executed, it will attempt to stop the job.
trans-unit.target: If Elastic Database Jobs detects a cancellation request for a job currently being executed, it will attempt to stop the job.

trans-unit.source: There are two different ways that Elastic Database Jobs can perform a cancellation:
trans-unit.target: There are two different ways that Elastic Database Jobs can perform a cancellation:

trans-unit.source: Canceling Currently Executing Tasks: If a cancellation is detected while a task is currently running, a cancellation will be attempted within the currently executing aspect of the task.
trans-unit.target: Canceling Currently Executing Tasks: If a cancellation is detected while a task is currently running, a cancellation will be attempted within the currently executing aspect of the task.

trans-unit.source: For example: If there is a long running query currently being performed when a cancellation is attempted, there will be an attempt to cancel the query.
trans-unit.target: For example: If there is a long running query currently being performed when a cancellation is attempted, there will be an attempt to cancel the query.

trans-unit.source: Canceling Task Retries: If a cancellation is detected by the control thread before a task is launched for execution, the control thread will avoid launching the task and declare the request as canceled.
trans-unit.target: Canceling Task Retries: If a cancellation is detected by the control thread before a task is launched for execution, the control thread will avoid launching the task and declare the request as canceled.

trans-unit.source: If a job cancellation is requested for a parent job, the cancellation request will be honored for the parent job and for all of its child jobs.
trans-unit.target: If a job cancellation is requested for a parent job, the cancellation request will be honored for the parent job and for all of its child jobs.

trans-unit.source: To submit a cancellation request, use the Stop-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet and set the JobExecutionId parameter.
trans-unit.target: To submit a cancellation request, use the Stop-AzureSqlJobExecution cmdlet and set the JobExecutionId parameter.

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database jobs supports asynchronous deletion of jobs.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database jobs supports asynchronous deletion of jobs.

trans-unit.source: A job can be marked for deletion and the system will delete the job and all its job history after all job executions have completed for the job.
trans-unit.target: A job can be marked for deletion and the system will delete the job and all its job history after all job executions have completed for the job.

trans-unit.source: The system will not automatically cancel active job executions.
trans-unit.target: The system will not automatically cancel active job executions.

trans-unit.source: Instead, Stop-AzureSqlJobExecution must be invoked to cancel active job executions.
trans-unit.target: Instead, Stop-AzureSqlJobExecution must be invoked to cancel active job executions.

trans-unit.source: To trigger job deletion, use the Remove-AzureSqlJob cmdlet and set the JobName parameter.
trans-unit.target: To trigger job deletion, use the Remove-AzureSqlJob cmdlet and set the JobName parameter.

trans-unit.source: Custom database targets can be defined in Elastic Database jobs which can be used either for execution directly or for inclusion within a custom database group.
trans-unit.target: Custom database targets can be defined in Elastic Database jobs which can be used either for execution directly or for inclusion within a custom database group.

trans-unit.source: Since Elastic Database pools are not yet directly supported via the PowerShell APIs, you simply create a custom database target and custom database collection target which encompasses all the databases in the pool.
trans-unit.target: Since Elastic Database pools are not yet directly supported via the PowerShell APIs, you simply create a custom database target and custom database collection target which encompasses all the databases in the pool.

trans-unit.source: Set the following variables to reflect the desired database information:
trans-unit.target: Set the following variables to reflect the desired database information:

trans-unit.source: A custom database collection target can be defined to enable execution across multiple defined database targets.
trans-unit.target: A custom database collection target can be defined to enable execution across multiple defined database targets.

trans-unit.source: After a database group is created, databases can be associated to the custom collection target.
trans-unit.target: After a database group is created, databases can be associated to the custom collection target.

trans-unit.source: Set the following variables to reflect the desired custom collection target configuration:
trans-unit.target: Set the following variables to reflect the desired custom collection target configuration:

trans-unit.source: Database targets can be associated with custom database collection targets to create a group of databases.
trans-unit.target: Database targets can be associated with custom database collection targets to create a group of databases.

trans-unit.source: Whenever a job is created that targets a custom database collection target, it will be expanded to target the databases associated to the group at the time of execution.
trans-unit.target: Whenever a job is created that targets a custom database collection target, it will be expanded to target the databases associated to the group at the time of execution.

trans-unit.source: Add the desired database to a specific custom collection:
trans-unit.target: Add the desired database to a specific custom collection:

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-AzureSqlJobTarget cmdlet to retrieve the child databases within a custom database collection target.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-AzureSqlJobTarget cmdlet to retrieve the child databases within a custom database collection target.

trans-unit.source: Use the New-AzureSqlJob cmdlet to create a job against a group of databases defined by a custom database collection target.
trans-unit.target: Use the New-AzureSqlJob cmdlet to create a job against a group of databases defined by a custom database collection target.

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database jobs will expand the job into multiple child jobs each corresponding to a database associated with the custom database collection target and ensure that the script is executed against each database.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database jobs will expand the job into multiple child jobs each corresponding to a database associated with the custom database collection target and ensure that the script is executed against each database.

trans-unit.source: Again, it is important that scripts are idempotent to be resilient to retries.
trans-unit.target: Again, it is important that scripts are idempotent to be resilient to retries.

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database jobs supports executing a query across a group of databases and sends the results to a specified database’s table.
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database jobs supports executing a query across a group of databases and sends the results to a specified database’s table.

trans-unit.source: The table can be queried after the fact to see the query’s results from each database.
trans-unit.target: The table can be queried after the fact to see the query’s results from each database.

trans-unit.source: This provides an asynchronous mechanism to execute a query across many databases.
trans-unit.target: This provides an asynchronous mechanism to execute a query across many databases.

trans-unit.source: Failure cases such as one of the databases being temporarily unavailable are handled automatically via retries.
trans-unit.target: Failure cases such as one of the databases being temporarily unavailable are handled automatically via retries.

trans-unit.source: The specified destination table will be automatically created if it does not yet exist matching the schema of the returned result set.
trans-unit.target: The specified destination table will be automatically created if it does not yet exist matching the schema of the returned result set.

trans-unit.source: If a script execution returns multiple result sets, Elastic Database jobs will only send the first one to the provided destination table.
trans-unit.target: If a script execution returns multiple result sets, Elastic Database jobs will only send the first one to the provided destination table.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell script can be used to execute a script collecting its results into a specified table.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell script can be used to execute a script collecting its results into a specified table.

trans-unit.source: This script assumes that a T-SQL script has been created which outputs a single result set and a custom database collection target has been created.
trans-unit.target: This script assumes that a T-SQL script has been created which outputs a single result set and a custom database collection target has been created.

trans-unit.source: Set the following to reflect the desired script, credentials, and execution target:
trans-unit.target: Set the following to reflect the desired script, credentials, and execution target:

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell script can be used to create a reoccurring schedule.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell script can be used to create a reoccurring schedule.

trans-unit.source: This script uses a minute interval, but New-AzureSqlJobSchedule also supports -DayInterval, -HourInterval, -MonthInterval, and -WeekInterval parameters.
trans-unit.target: This script uses a minute interval, but New-AzureSqlJobSchedule also supports -DayInterval, -HourInterval, -MonthInterval, and -WeekInterval parameters.

trans-unit.source: Schedules that execute only once can be created by passing -OneTime.
trans-unit.target: Schedules that execute only once can be created by passing -OneTime.

trans-unit.source: Create a new schedule:
trans-unit.target: Create a new schedule:

trans-unit.source: A job trigger can be defined to have a job executed according to a time schedule.
trans-unit.target: A job trigger can be defined to have a job executed according to a time schedule.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell script can be used to create a job trigger.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell script can be used to create a job trigger.

trans-unit.source: Set the following variables to correspond to the desired job and schedule:
trans-unit.target: Set the following variables to correspond to the desired job and schedule:

trans-unit.source: To discontinue reoccurring job execution through a job trigger, the job trigger can be removed.
trans-unit.target: To discontinue reoccurring job execution through a job trigger, the job trigger can be removed.

trans-unit.source: Remove a job trigger to stop a job from being executed according to a schedule using the Remove-AzureSqlJobTrigger cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Remove a job trigger to stop a job from being executed according to a schedule using the Remove-AzureSqlJobTrigger cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can import the results from of a query to an Excel file.
trans-unit.target: You can import the results from of a query to an Excel file.

trans-unit.source: Launch Excel 2013.
trans-unit.target: Launch Excel 2013.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Data ribbon.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Data ribbon.

trans-unit.source: Click From Other Sources and click From SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Click From Other Sources and click From SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Excel import from other sources</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Excel import from other sources</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Data Connection Wizard type the server name and login credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the Data Connection Wizard type the server name and login credentials.

trans-unit.source: Then click Next.
trans-unit.target: Then click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the dialog box Select the database that contains the data you want, select the ElasticDBQuery database.
trans-unit.target: In the dialog box Select the database that contains the data you want, select the ElasticDBQuery database.

trans-unit.source: Select the Customers table in the list view and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Select the Customers table in the list view and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Then click Finish.
trans-unit.target: Then click Finish.

trans-unit.source: In the Import Data form, under Select how you want to view this data in your workbook, select Table and click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Import Data form, under Select how you want to view this data in your workbook, select Table and click OK.

trans-unit.source: All the rows from Customers table, stored in different shards populate the Excel sheet.
trans-unit.target: All the rows from Customers table, stored in different shards populate the Excel sheet.

trans-unit.source: You can now use Excel’s powerful data functions.
trans-unit.target: You can now use Excel’s powerful data functions.

trans-unit.source: You can use the connection string with your server name, database name and credentials to connect your BI and data integration tools to the elastic query database.
trans-unit.target: You can use the connection string with your server name, database name and credentials to connect your BI and data integration tools to the elastic query database.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that SQL Server is supported as a data source for your tool.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that SQL Server is supported as a data source for your tool.

trans-unit.source: You can refer to the elastic query database and external tables just like any other SQL Server database and SQL Server tables that you would connect to with your tool.
trans-unit.target: You can refer to the elastic query database and external tables just like any other SQL Server database and SQL Server tables that you would connect to with your tool.

trans-unit.source: There is no additional charge for using the Elastic Database Query feature.
trans-unit.target: There is no additional charge for using the Elastic Database Query feature.

trans-unit.source: However, at this time this feature is available only on premium databases as an end point, but the shards can be of any service tier.
trans-unit.target: However, at this time this feature is available only on premium databases as an end point, but the shards can be of any service tier.

trans-unit.source: For pricing information see <linkText>SQL Database Pricing Details</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For pricing information see <linkText>SQL Database Pricing Details</linkText><title></title>.
